name: Pearl Harbor National Memorial
description: At Pearl Harbor National Memorial, we honor the lives affected by the December 7, 1941, attack. This pivotal moment in global history marked the United States' entry into World War II, impacting nations and communities worldwide. Join us in reflecting on this shared history and its lasting significance in the pursuit of peace.

operatingHours.description:
Pearl Harbor National Memorial, Visitor Center and parking lots are open from 7 AM to 5 PM seven days a week. 

Pearl Harbor National Memorial, Visitor Center and parking lots are closed on Thanksgiving, December 25th, and January 1st.

climate.weatherDescription: Hawaii has two seasons – winter (ho'oilo) and summer (kau wela) – and temperatures don't change drastically the way they do in the mainland United States. During the day, expect temperatures in the mid-70s to the mid-80s all year around. Expect lows in the winter months (November to March) to be around 60 degrees. The Hawaiian winter is also considered the rainy season, and flash floods are not uncommon. You can expect to see lots of rainbows as the rain clears.

images.title: The USS Utah
images.altText: The USS Utah off the coast of Ford Island
images.caption: The USS Utah lays where she fell on the north side of Ford Island. This decision was made in 1944 after several attempts at raising the ship failed. The quiet decision was made to leave the bodies of 58 crewmen onboard, considering them buried at sea.

images.title: USS Arizona Memorial
images.altText: Visitors at the USS Arizona Memorial
images.caption: Daily visitation to the USS Arizona Memorial is often more than 4,000 visitors.

images.title: The USS Oklahoma Memorial
images.caption: After receiving seven to nine torpedo hits on the port (left) side, the USS Oklahoma capsized in roughly 20 minutes after the attack began. Over 400 men were trapped inside, of which only 32 were rescued.
